pageContext.claim: “If you look at the kind of numbers that we've produced for Hispanic or black for Asian, it's nine times greater the percentage gain than it was under in three years than it was under eight years of the two of them, to put it nicely.”
pageContext.analysis: This is a misleading statistic ginned up in part by the fact that Barack Obama took office in the midst of the Great Recession. (The stat also relies on numbers that the Census Bureau says are sketchy because a pandemic-induced survey bias.) It took almost eight years for Black median incomes to recover from the recession, meaning any gain would be small indeed. Incomes finally started to rise late in Obama's term, and Trump inherited the continued increase. So from a low base, Trump is able to tout a nine-times gain. But the statistic mostly demonstrates the idiocy of measuring economic trends by presidential terms. (Of course, once Trump completes his term, his economic record is going to take a beating from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.)
